newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenian shares firm, Lej sought.
newsitem.headline: Slovenian shares firm, Lej sought.

text.p: Slovenia's SBI index firmed one percent on Wednesday, pushed up by foreign demand that focused on pharmaceutical producer Lek.
The blue-chip SBI rose 16.89 points to 1,557.56.
Lek, the most actively traded share, firmed 1.12 percent to 36,000 tolars on volume of 2,597 shares for total turnover of 93.4 million tolars.
Traders said strong foreign interest should contribute to further growth over the coming months.
"I believe shares will continue rising to the end of the year, with downward corrections from time to time, due to the strong foreign demand," said Alain Al Soufi of brokerage BPH.
He forecast the SBI would reach 1,650 points by the end of this month and over 2,000 points by year-end.
Overall 14 shares rose, one was unchanged, five fell and eight were untraded.
Turnover fell to 229.6 million tolars from 362 million.
Financial consultancy Primofin was the top gainer, closing 10 percent higher at 9,900 tolars on volume of 10 shares in a rebound after Friday's fall of 14.29 percent.

Trader Kovinotehna led decliners, down 4.72 percent to 505 tolars on volume of 3,619 shares but analysts said the share should recover shortly as the price was low considering the firm's good business results.
"Kovinotehna is probably the most undervalued share on our bourse market," Al Soufi said.
